subject: testing threaded applications

messageBody:
Hey all,

I am building a plugin engine (www.platonos.org) where
I would like to provide some unit tests to test the
ability of the engine handling threaded plugin
creation requests. In a nutshell, when a plugin, which
is loaded by its own classloader, is being
instantiated, it is possible another thread from
another plugin that depends on it is ALSO trying to
access it. The very first time any class within the
classpath of a plugin is asked for by the JVM, the
plugin lifecycle class is created first.

So I want a way to try to simulate several threads
accessing the same one plugin, and some way to "test"
that the first thread to access it "locks" the plugin
during creation and the other threads wait (we have
synchronized the block of code that creates the
plugin) until the creation is done. THEN, they should
not be able to cause the plugin they are acessing to
be created again, because it's state now indicates its
already created.

Without diving any further into the engine, feel free
to check out the source. Is there any way to test
this? I am thinking in the constructor of the plugin
being accessed by many threads, put a sleep call to
"delay" how fast the plugin is created, so that the
other threads have time to try to access it.

Thanks.
